Appendix A Proofs

A.1. Proofs for Section 3

Proof of Proposition 1.

The proof is largely the same as that in past work (Salimi et al., 2019). Note that for any choice of K⊇A𝐴𝐾K\supseteq A, if all the directed paths go through at least one attribute in K𝐾K then intervening on K𝐾K, that is d​o​(K=k)𝑑𝑜𝐾𝑘do(K=k) then at least one of the edges in the path will always be severed. This will separate all nodes in O𝑂O from those in P𝑃P and thus any further intervention on P𝑃P cannot influence the distribution of O𝑂O. ∎

Proof of Proposition 3.

Here, we show that given a set K⊇A𝐴𝐾K\supseteq A that the probability of the outcome is dependent only on the intervention on K𝐾K and is the same regardless of the value of p𝑝p. We rely on a fact from (Pearl, 1995) namely the following equivalence on the do operator.

(5) P​(O=o|d​o​(K=k),d​o​(P=p))=P​(O=o|d​o​(K=k))if(O⟂⟂P|K)P​K¯\begin{split}P(O=o|do(K=k),do(P=p))=P(O=o|do(K=k))\\ \text{if}(O\perp\!\!\!\perp P|K)_{\overline{PK}}\end{split}

Where P​K¯¯𝑃𝐾\overline{PK} denotes the distribution derived by removing all edges pointing to attributes in P𝑃P and K𝐾K.

This will allow us to show that the outcome is independent of any intervention on P𝑃P once we have already intervened on K𝐾K,i.e., applying the d​o𝑑𝑜do operator on P𝑃P does not change the probability. In particular, we will be able to show that P​[O=o|d​o​(Pi=0),d​o​(K=k)]=P​[O=o|d​o​(Pi=1),d​o​(K=k)]=P​[O=o|d​o​(K=k)]𝑃delimited-[]𝑂conditional𝑜𝑑𝑜subscript𝑃𝑖0𝑑𝑜𝐾𝑘𝑃delimited-[]𝑂conditional𝑜𝑑𝑜subscript𝑃𝑖1𝑑𝑜𝐾𝑘𝑃delimited-[]𝑂conditional𝑜𝑑𝑜𝐾𝑘P[O=o|do(P_{i}=0),do(K=k)]=P[O=o|do(P_{i}=1),do(K=k)]=P[O=o|do(K=k)], which is the definition of K-fairness.

We also highly rely on the concept of d-separation a notion that can be directly observed on the graph. We say two attributes X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y are d-connected (and thus not d-separated) conditioned on a set of attributes Z𝑍Z if any of the following hold.

  • •

    There exists an undirected path from X𝑋X to Y𝑌Y that is not blocked by Z𝑍Z

  • •

    There exists an undirected path from X𝑋X to Y𝑌Y that is not blocked by a collider a∉Z𝑎𝑍a\notin Z

Where a collider is an attribute along the undirected path where both edges in the path are directed towards that attribute.

Let K𝐾K be any superset of A𝐴A which shares no elements with P𝑃P. Note that in any directed Marginals-MSTthere is exactly one undirected path between any attribute in P𝑃P and any attribute in O𝑂O. Likewise this path is always blocked by at least one attribute in K𝐾K.

Therefore the path from the attribute in P𝑃P to an attribute in O𝑂O must have one of the structures shown in Figure 9 where X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y denote arbitrary sets of nodes along the path with arbitrary directed edges between them. Double edges denote an edge that can be in any arbitrary direction. ΠΠ\Pi denotes an attribute in P𝑃P, ΩΩ\Omega denotes an attribute in O𝑂O and α𝛼\alpha denotes an attribute in A𝐴A. Note that the path must either pass through α𝛼\alpha (the first case), have edges that go to α𝛼\alpha (the second case) or have edges that originate from α𝛼\alpha (the third case).

In the graph P​K¯¯𝑃𝐾\overline{PK} where all edges going into attributes in P𝑃P and K𝐾K are removed each of these cases introduces a d-separation between ΩΩ\Omega and ΠΠ\Pi when conditioned on K𝐾K. In the first case, the edge going into α𝛼\alpha is removed and as such the path is severed. In the second case, both edges going to α𝛼\alpha are removed and the path is severed. In the third case, no edges are severed but conditioning on α𝛼\alpha d-separates ΠΠ\Pi and ΩΩ\Omega since it blocks the path and is not a collider.

Since the dataset is Markov compatible with the graph then the d-separation of ΩΩ\Omega and ΠΠ\Pi imply that the two are independent when conditioned on α𝛼\alpha. Since they are conditionally independent we can use Equation 5 to show that P​(O=o|d​o​(K=k),d​o​(P=p))𝑃𝑂conditional𝑜𝑑𝑜𝐾𝑘𝑑𝑜𝑃𝑝P(O=o|do(K=k),do(P=p)) is the same regardless of the intervention on P𝑃P. Therefore, the distribution satisfies K-fairness. Likewise since K𝐾K could be an arbitrary superset of A𝐴A then the distribution also satisfies justifiable fairness. ∎

Proof of Proposition 7.

We show that, given an instance of 3-SAT, we can define an equivalent instance of the decision version of FDPSynth, where any maximal spanning tree will correspond to a satisfying 3-SAT assignment.

Construction. First we describe the construction of a graph 𝒢𝒢{\mathcal{G}} from a 3-SAT instance φ𝜑\varphi with m𝑚m clauses and n𝑛n literals. We create an assignment gadget (Figure 4) for each literal in φ𝜑\varphi. This contains a protected attribute ΠisubscriptΠ𝑖\Pi_{i} and edges from the protected attribute to two additional attributes representing the literal and its negation (xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} and ¬xisubscript𝑥𝑖\neg x_{i} respectively). For each clause in φ𝜑\varphi we create a 3-way OR gadget (Figure 5). The α𝛼\alpha nodes in the OR gadget are admissible attributes and the ΩΩ\Omega nodes are outcome attributes. Each of the inputs for the 3-way or gate (x1,x2,x3subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑥3x_{1},x_{2},x_{3}) are then connected to the corresponding literal in the assignment gadget using a weight 3 edge. We now prove that there is a solution to the decision version of FDPSynth (Definition 6) with k=22​m+2​n𝑘22𝑚2𝑛k=22m+2n

To build the intuition behind the 3-way OR gadget we first describe the 2-way OR gadget (Figure 10) and build upon that. This gadget takes two inputs x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} and x2subscript𝑥2x_{2}. These may be either connected to an assignment gadget or the output of another gadget. Note that in order to make the maximum spanning tree across this substructure both edges with weight 2 must be taken and at least one edge with weight 1 must be taken resulting in a total weight of 555. We recall that we consider a literal to be set to F​a​l​s​e𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒False if there exists an unblocked path from a protected attribute to it. We now consider the output of the two way OR gadget O𝑂O. This node will be considered set to F​a​l​s​e𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒False if there is an unblocked path between a protected attribute and O𝑂O. For either of the possible maximum spanning trees on the 2-way OR gadget only one of the inputs can have a path to O𝑂O that is blocked by α𝛼\alpha. Therefore, for either of the maximum spanning trees, if both inputs are set to F​a​l​s​e𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒False only one of them may be blocked by α𝛼\alpha and the other will have a direct edge to the output resulting in an output of F​a​l​s​e𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒False. As such any maximum spanning tree on the 2-way OR gadget evaluates to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True if at least one of its inputs evaluates to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True resulting in the same functionality as an OR gate. Similar to traditional OR gates in order to construct the 3-way OR gadget we simply apply two 2-way OR gadgets together with the only exception being that the output of the second 2-way or gadget is an outcome attribute. This ensures that if a tree over the 3 way or gadget has the maximum weight (13) and satisfies Proposition 1 then it corresponds to a satisfying assignment for the corresponding clause.

iff φ𝜑\varphi has a satisfying assignment.

Proof. (⇒⇒\Rightarrow) Assume that we have a fair Marginals-MST T𝑇T of the constructed graph G𝐺G. If T𝑇T has the maximum weight of 22​m+2​n22𝑚2𝑛22m+2n, where m𝑚m is the number of clauses and n𝑛n is the number of literals, and then the assignment to each literal can be read by looking at each assignment gadget. In T𝑇T only one of the edges from each assignment gadget will be kept due to the tree condition. Whichever node has an edge to the protected attribute ΠisubscriptΠ𝑖\Pi_{i} will be set to F​a​l​s​e𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒False and the other will be set to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True. This assignment is consistent as the literal in the assignment gadget in Figure 4 will have an edge to every 3-way OR gadgets that corresponds to clauses which have that literal. This ensures that all 3-way OR clauses which have x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} will have an edge to x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} in the assignment gadget and those that have ¬x1subscript𝑥1\neg x_{1} have an edge to ¬x1subscript𝑥1\neg x_{1} in the assignment gadget. Since only one edge can be taken in the assignment gadget then either x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} or ¬x1subscript𝑥1\neg x_{1} can be set to F​a​l​s​e𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒False but not both.

Recall that in order for the minimum spanning tree over the 3-way OR gadget to be maximum and fair at least one literal must be set to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True. Because of this any global Marginals-MSTof the maximum weight of 13​m+5​n13𝑚5𝑛13m+5n ensues that each clause has at least one literal set to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True.

(⇐⇐\Leftarrow) Here we show that given a satisfying assignment to φ𝜑\varphi, a𝑎a, we can construct a unique fair Marginals-MST on G𝐺G. In order to show that a minimum spanning tree of G𝐺G always corresponds to a 3-SAT solution we will rely heavily on the following fact about MSTs: for any spanning tree on graph G𝐺G to be an MST all the subtrees on smaller connected components must also be a minimum spanning trees for each of those components. This allows us to reason about the smaller parts of the tree (mainly the OR gadget) without considering the rest of the tree.

Now given a satisfying assignment to φ𝜑\varphi, a𝑎a, we can construct the corresponding fair Marginals-MST. First, select the edge that correctly assigns the attributes according to the assignment gadget. That is if the assignment sets x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True select (Π​¬,x1)Πsubscript𝑥1(\Pi\neg,x_{1}) in Figure 4 and (Π,x1)Πsubscript𝑥1(\Pi,x_{1}) otherwise. Then for each 3-way OR gadget (Figure 5) take all four weight 2 edges.

In the case of the 3-way OR gadget all edges will refer to the notation of Figure 5. Since a𝑎a is a satisfying assignment for φ𝜑\varphi, at least one of the 3 literals xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} will evaluate to T​r​u​e𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒True . If this literal is connected to the first 2-way OR gadget , select its 1 weight edge to be connected to the output (xi,O)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑂(x_{i},O) and the 1 weight edge from the output to the outcome node (x′,Ω)superscript𝑥′Ω(x^{\prime},\Omega). If the literal is connected to the second 2-way OR gadget either weight 1 edge (x1,O)subscript𝑥1𝑂(x_{1},O) or (x2,O)subscript𝑥2𝑂(x_{2},O) from the first 2 weight or gadget can be selected and the weight 1 edge from the literal to the outcome (x3,Ω)subscript𝑥3Ω(x_{3},\Omega) will be selected in the second 2-way OR gadget. We give an example of such a 3-WAY OR gadget in Figure 11 where the edges to be taken are highlighted in blue. This corresponds to the assignment (x1=T​r​u​e,x2=F​a​l​s​e,x3=F​a​l​s​e)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥1𝑇𝑟𝑢𝑒formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥2𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒subscript𝑥3𝐹𝑎𝑙𝑠𝑒(x_{1}=True,x_{2}=False,x_{3}=False). Taking these edges both maximizes the weight as it takes all the 2 weight edges and only one 1 weight edge from either 2-way or gadget. This also ensures that the resulting Marginals-MST is fair since each outcome in the 3-way OR gadget has paths all blocked by admissible attributes. In each case for any maximal spanning tree at most one path from the literals to the outcome may be blocked since only one of the weigh 1 edges can be taken.

∎

Proof of Lemma 8.

Here we first show that we can create a set of random variables A,B,C,D𝐴𝐵𝐶𝐷A,B,C,D which results in the graph where B,C,D𝐵𝐶𝐷B,C,D all have arbitrary mutual information with A𝐴A and there is no mutual information between any other pair of variables. From there we demonstrate that we can extend this construction to an arbitrary number of variables each with their arbitrary weight. We argue that this construction is sufficient to be able to construct a graph with the structure of the 3-way OR gadget.

Let B,C𝐵𝐶B,C and D𝐷D be discrete uniform random variables with domain size n𝑛n for some n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}. Let A𝐴A be the discrete random variable with the following probability distribution.

{A=BWith Probability xA=CWith Probability yA=DWith Probability zA=0With Probability λcases𝐴𝐵With Probability x𝐴𝐶With Probability y𝐴𝐷With Probability z𝐴0With Probability λ\begin{cases}A=B&\text{With Probability $x$}\\ A=C&\text{With Probability $y$}\\ A=D&\text{With Probability $z$}\\ A=0&\text{With Probability $\lambda$}\end{cases}

Where x+y+z+λ=1𝑥𝑦𝑧𝜆1x+y+z+\lambda=1. The entropy of A𝐴A from is as follows.

(6) H​(A)=−(x​log⁡(x/n)+y​log⁡(y/n)+z​log⁡(z/n)+(λ)​l​o​g​(λ))𝐻𝐴𝑥𝑥𝑛𝑦𝑦𝑛𝑧𝑧𝑛𝜆𝑙𝑜𝑔𝜆\begin{split}H(A)=&\\ &-(x\log(x/n)+y\log(y/n)+z\log(z/n)+(\lambda)log(\lambda))\end{split}

Likewise the conditional entropy is as follows.

(7) H​(A|B)=−(x​log⁡(x)+y​log⁡(y/n)+z​log⁡(z/n)+(λ)​l​o​g​(λ))𝐻conditional𝐴𝐵𝑥𝑥𝑦𝑦𝑛𝑧𝑧𝑛𝜆𝑙𝑜𝑔𝜆\begin{split}H(A|B)=&\\ &-(x\log(x)+y\log(y/n)+z\log(z/n)+(\lambda)log(\lambda))\end{split}

As such the mutual information is as follows.

(8) I​(A;B)=H​(A)−H​(A|B)=x​log⁡(x)−x​log⁡(x/n)=x​(log⁡(x)−log⁡(x/n))=x​log⁡(n)𝐼𝐴𝐵𝐻𝐴𝐻conditional𝐴𝐵𝑥𝑥𝑥𝑥𝑛𝑥𝑥𝑥𝑛𝑥𝑛\begin{split}I(A;B)=H(A)-H(A|B)=&\\ &x\log(x)-x\log(x/n)=\\ &x(\log(x)-\log(x/n))=\\ &x\log(n)\end{split}

The same can be done for the other random variables B𝐵B and C𝐶C. It is clear that B,C𝐵𝐶B,C and D𝐷D have mutual information 00 since they are all uniform random variables.

The only constraint is that x+y+z+λ=1𝑥𝑦𝑧𝜆1x+y+z+\lambda=1. Given a sufficiently large n𝑛n we can set x​log⁡(n)𝑥𝑛x\log(n) to be any arbitrary value and the same goes for the other two attributes. For example if for example we would like to make the relationship between O,x′,α𝑂superscript𝑥′𝛼O,x^{\prime},\alpha and ΩΩ\Omega shown in Figure 5 we would do the following construction.

Let A𝐴A take the place of x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime}, B𝐵B take the place of O𝑂O, C take the place of α𝛼\alpha and D𝐷D take the place of ΩΩ\Omega. Let n=212=4096,x=14,y=16,z=112formulae-sequence𝑛superscript2124096formulae-sequence𝑥14formulae-sequence𝑦16𝑧112n=2^{12}=4096,x=\frac{1}{4},y=\frac{1}{6},z=\frac{1}{12} and λ=12𝜆12\lambda=\frac{1}{2}. First these values of x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z and λ𝜆\lambda satisfy the constraint as 14+16+112+12=11416112121\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{2}=1. Likewise these probabilities give us the desired mutual probabilities as x​log⁡(n)=14​log⁡(4096)=3𝑥𝑛1440963x\log(n)=\frac{1}{4}\log(4096)=3. Likewise y​log⁡(n)=2𝑦𝑛2y\log(n)=2 and z​log⁡(n)=1𝑧𝑛1z\log(n)=1 which is what we need for A=x′𝐴superscript𝑥′A=x^{\prime}, B=α𝐵𝛼B=\alpha, C=Ω𝐶ΩC=\Omega, and D=O𝐷𝑂D=O in Figure 5.

We can extend this to any arbitrary number of edges as well as any value of mutual information. This only requires a larger value of n𝑛n. If we would like ζ𝜁\zeta edges with the maximum mutual information I𝐼I n𝑛n must be at least 2ζ​Isuperscript2𝜁𝐼2^{\zeta I}

∎

A.2. Proofs for Section 4

Proof of Proposition 2(1).

Using the Gaussian Mechanism (line 1) with scale σ𝜎\sigma satisfies (α,12​σ2)𝛼12superscript𝜎2(\alpha,\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}})-RDP. If we set σ=r2​ρ𝜎𝑟2𝜌\sigma=\sqrt{\frac{r}{2\rho}} this becomes (α,α​ρr)𝛼𝛼𝜌𝑟(\alpha,\alpha\frac{\rho}{r})-RDP. This is invoked r𝑟r times and is the only line that directly accesses private data thus by Theorem 5 it thus satisfies (α,α​ρ)𝛼𝛼𝜌(\alpha,\alpha\rho)-RDP. ∎

Proof of Proposition 2(2).

When Algorithm 1 creates incomplete spanning tree to add to the priority queue it rejects any partial spanning tree that violate Proposition 1. Therefore the resulting output satisfies Proposition 1. ∎

Proof of Proposition 4.

Let G𝐺G be a graph over the input database D𝐷D where the nodes represent attributes and edges represent mutual information between attributes. Consider the case where each edge has uniform weight (by Lemma 8 such a database exists). In this case, the weight of any partial spanning tree is merely the number of edges in the partial tree. As such, Algorithm 1 will create every possible spanning trees before selecting any of them . There are |𝒜||𝒜|−2superscript𝒜𝒜2|{\mathcal{A}}|^{|{\mathcal{A}}|-2} possible spanning trees resulting in the worst case time complexity. ∎

Proof of Proposition 5(1).

Line 8 satisfies (α,α​18​ϵ2)𝛼𝛼18superscriptitalic-ϵ2(\alpha,\alpha\frac{1}{8}\epsilon^{2})-RDP. This is the only line that accesses the private data. If we set ϵ=8​ρr−1italic-ϵ8𝜌𝑟1\epsilon=\sqrt{\frac{8\rho}{r-1}} this becomes (α,α​ρr−1)𝛼𝛼𝜌𝑟1(\alpha,\alpha\frac{\rho}{r-1})-RDP. This is invoked r−1𝑟1r-1 times and by Theorem 5 it thus satisfies (α,α​ρ)𝛼𝛼𝜌(\alpha,\alpha\rho)-RDP ∎

Proof of Proposition 5 (2).

In line 2, Algorithm 2 removes any edges from nodes in O𝑂O that do not go to nodes in O∪A𝑂𝐴O\cup A. This results in a Marginals-MST where all of the neighbors of nodes in O𝑂O are in O∪A𝑂𝐴O\cup A. Any path from attributes in to attributes in O𝑂O must pass through a neighbor of the attribute in O𝑂O and therefore must pass through an attribute in A∪O𝐴𝑂A\cup O. Therefore by Proposition 6 the output of Algorithm 2 is a fair Marginals-MST. ∎

Proof of Proposition 6.

Assume that all the neighbors of nodes in O𝑂O are in O∪A𝑂𝐴O\cup A. Any path from a node in P𝑃P to a node in o∈O𝑜𝑂o\in O must pass through at least one of o𝑜o’s neighbors. If that neighbor is in A𝐴A then the path is blocked by an admissible attribute therefore satisfying Proposition 1. If that neighbor was in O𝑂O then the path must also go through one of its neighbors which must be in O∪A𝑂𝐴O\cup A. Since only nodes in A𝐴A are allowed to have edges to nodes outside of O∪A𝑂𝐴O\cup A then the path must go through at least one of these nodes therefore blocking the path and satisfying Proposition 1.

To prove the converse we use a proof by contradiction. Assume T𝑇T is a fair Marginals-MST, the problem setting is saturated, and that there is an edge from a node o∈O𝑜𝑂o\in O to a node x∉O∪A𝑥𝑂𝐴x\notin O\cup A. By the definition of the saturated case since x𝑥x is not in O∪A𝑂𝐴O\cup A then it must be in P𝑃P. Since x𝑥x is in P𝑃P and is neighbor of o𝑜o then there exists a direction of edges (x𝑥x-¿o𝑜o) such that o𝑜o is directly dependent on x𝑥x resulting in a violation of Definition 2.

∎

Proof of Proposition 7.

Algorithm 2 greedily selects |𝒜|−1𝒜1|{\mathcal{A}}|-1 edges one at a time using the exponential mechanism (lines 2-2). This process is done exactly |𝒜|−1𝒜1|{\mathcal{A}}|-1 times resulting in a time complexity of |𝒜|−1𝒜1|{\mathcal{A}}|-1. ∎
